title: Harvest Practices
description: Requirements for safe harvest practices including harvest procedures, product handling standards, dropped product protocols, field packing hygiene, temperature control, and product protection during and after harvest

requirements.text: Are there documented harvest procedures that address food safety requirements including product handling, hygiene, and contamination prevention?
mandatoryStatements: Written harvest procedures are documented
Procedures address proper product handling techniques
Procedures address hygiene requirements during harvest
Procedures address contamination prevention measures
Procedures address what to do if contamination occurs
Procedures specify when harvest should be delayed or stopped
Procedures are communicated to harvest crew and supervisors
Procedures are reviewed and updated annually
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of harvest procedures, verification during harvest observations
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily supervision to ensure procedures are followed, immediate correction of deviations

requirements.text: Is product handled in a manner that minimizes physical damage and contamination risk?
mandatoryStatements: Product is handled gently to minimize bruising and damage
Product is not thrown or dropped
Overfilling of containers is avoided
Product is protected from contamination during handling
Workers follow proper lifting and placement techniques
Damaged product is identified and segregated
Handling procedures prevent cross-contamination
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily observation of product handling practices during harvest
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous supervision, immediate correction of improper handling

requirements.text: Is product that is dropped on the ground during harvest not placed into harvest containers and is it segregated from harvested product?
mandatoryStatements: Product dropped on ground is not harvested
Dropped product is not placed in harvest containers
Dropped product is clearly segregated from good product
Policy on dropped product is communicated to harvest crew
Supervisors enforce dropped product policy
Dropped product is disposed of or diverted to non-food use
Violations of dropped product policy result in corrective action
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily observation during harvest to ensure dropped product is not collected
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous supervision, zero tolerance enforcement of dropped product policy

requirements.text: If product is packed in the field, are food safety and hygiene controls in place equivalent to those in a packing facility?
mandatoryStatements: Field packing area is established and maintained
Packing surfaces are clean and sanitary
Packing equipment and materials are clean
Workers follow hygiene requirements during packing
Hand washing is available at packing area
Toilet facilities are accessible to packers
Product is protected from contamination during packing
Packing area is free from debris, pests, and other contamination sources
Same hygiene standards as indoor packing are applied
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily inspection of field packing operations and hygiene compliance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous supervision of field packing, immediate correction of hygiene violations

requirements.text: Is harvested product protected from contamination during field holding and transport?
mandatoryStatements: Harvested product is covered or protected while in field
Product containers are kept off the ground or on clean pallets
Product is protected from sun, rain, dust, and other environmental contamination
Product is protected from animal and pest access
Transport vehicles are clean and sanitary
Product is not transported with potential contaminants
Product is handled to maintain cold chain if required
Field holding time is minimized
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily inspection of product protection during field holding and transport
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous monitoring, immediate correction if product exposed to contamination risk

requirements.text: If product requires cooling or temperature control, is it cooled promptly and maintained at proper temperature?
mandatoryStatements: Product requiring cooling is moved to cooling facility promptly after harvest
Target cooling temperatures are defined based on product requirements
Cooling rates are monitored and documented
Product temperature is monitored during storage
Cold chain is maintained during transport
Temperature recording devices are used and calibrated
Out-of-temperature events trigger corrective action
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily review of temperature records, verification of cooling performance
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous temperature monitoring, immediate action if temperatures exceed limits

requirements.text: Are harvest records maintained that enable traceability from field to first receiver?
mandatoryStatements: Harvest records are created for each harvest event
Records identify field or growing area harvested
Records identify harvest date
Records identify lot or batch code
Records link harvested product to receiving/packing records
Records enable one-step-back and one-step-forward traceability
Records are maintained for minimum 24 months
Records are organized and readily retrievable
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly trace exercise to verify traceability system, monthly audit of record completeness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily creation and filing of harvest records, immediate documentation for each harvest lot

requirements.text: Are harvest activities suspended or delayed when conditions pose a contamination risk (e.g., after flooding, during heavy rain, when animal contamination is detected)?
mandatoryStatements: Procedures specify conditions requiring harvest suspension
Harvest is suspended after flooding until assessment complete
Harvest may be delayed during heavy rain if it poses contamination risk
Harvest is immediately stopped if animal or human fecal contamination detected
Harvest is delayed if equipment or crew hygiene is inadequate
Decision authority for harvest suspension is clearly defined
Suspension decisions are documented with rationale
Conditions must be corrected and verified before resuming harvest
requirements.verificationExpectations: Review of any harvest suspension decisions and conditions
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Real-time assessment of harvest conditions, immediate suspension if contamination risk identified

capaInject: If harvest procedures not documented: develop comprehensive procedures within 14 days, train all harvest personnel immediately
If product handling causes damage or contamination: immediate retraining, enhanced supervision, revise handling procedures if needed
If dropped product placed in harvest containers: immediate removal of entire affected lot, retrain crew, zero tolerance enforcement going forward
If field packing hygiene inadequate: immediate correction, enhance hygiene controls to match packing facility standards
If product not protected during holding or transport: immediate implementation of protection measures, inspect all exposed product
If temperature control not maintained: immediate cooling, product evaluation, enhance temperature monitoring and control
If harvest records not maintained: implement record system immediately, train personnel on traceability requirements
If harvest continues under contamination risk conditions: immediate harvest suspension, assess all harvested product, implement stronger decision criteria
traceabilityInject: Harvest records must be traceable to specific fields, harvest dates, and lot codes
Harvest records must enable traceability from field to first receiver or packing facility
Temperature records must be traceable to specific lots and storage/transport events
Harvest suspension decisions must be traceable to specific conditions and resolution actions
